primary_trope.name: hidden_gem
primary_trope.hook_text: The best race you've never heard of.
primary_trope.mechanism: FOMO / loss aversion — the viewer is MISSING something. Losses feel 2.5x stronger than equivalent gains.

beats.label: HOOK + PROMISE
beats.narration: Should you race Niseko Gravel? I rated 328 gravel races on 14 dimensions. Niseko Gravel scored 51 out of 100. Solid tier. Here's what that actually means for your season.
beats.editing_note: STATE THE PREMISE IN 8 SECONDS. Clear value prop: 'I rated 328 races. Here's where this one lands.' This is the 8-second decision window. Viewers who stay past 15s are 58% more likely to finish.
beats.psych_mechanism: Curiosity gap (specific) + IKEA effect (viewer predicts the tier before reveal).

beats.label: THE COURSE
beats.narration: Niseko Gravel. Niseko, Hokkaido, Japan. 65 mi. Hokkaido mountain gravel.
beats.text_on_screen: Niseko Gravel | Niseko, Hokkaido, Japan | 65 mi
beats.editing_note: Let the course breathe. Show the route map, then cut to terrain-specific B-roll. This is the SETUP phase — grounding the viewer before the data analysis. Pacing: 25-40 sec cuts.

beats.label: THE SCORES — Top 8
beats.narration: The numbers. All fourteen of them. Adventure. 4 out of 5. Serious exploration vibes. Far from pavement. Courses access "forest roads where no one would usually go into" and special forest areas "not usually accessible" that open for limited periods. Experience. 4 out of 5. The kind of race that reshapes your season. Takahito Kishi describes the mountain pass terrain as "amazing – in every sense of the word. Length. 3 out of 5. Long enough to matter. Short enough to recover. Pro cyclist Takahito Kishi on his first gravel event: "It was surprisingly long so I took it easy from the start and enjoyed the scenery. Elevation. 3 out of 5. Enough vertical to remind you gravity exists. The 2022 Extra Long delivered 7,303 feet over 72 miles, while the Medium course provided 3,990 feet over 40 miles. Climate. 3 out of 5. Pack for two seasons. September 2022 brought perfect conditions—"the weather could not be better"—with gravel that was "dry, fast, and chunky. Race Quality. 3 out of 5. Solid production value. Takeshita praises the organizer's course design: "It was not monotone at all but very dynamic. Community. 3 out of 5. Genuine community feel. People stick around. Logistics. 2 out of 5. You'll figure it out. Eventually. Kae Takeshita notes "the event website had very little information available" before the 2022 event, creating pre-race uncertainty.
beats.editing_note: PROGRESSIVE RHYTHM: start tight (15-20 sec per dimension), slow down for the most interesting scores (30-40 sec). Each score: number appears, brief pause, explanation. Avatar reacts to extreme scores (5/5 = chef_kiss, 1/5 = facepalm). RE-ENGAGEMENT at 3:00 mark: insert a surprising score reveal or a meme reaction to break the pattern.

meme_insert.suggested_clip: avatar reaction to most extreme score

beats.label: THE SCORES — Also Scored
beats.narration: And the rest of the scorecard. Technicality. 2 out of 5. Some chunky bits. Nothing catastrophic. Altitude. 2 out of 5. Not enough altitude to blame for your pace. Prestige. 2 out of 5. Known in certain circles. Niche following. Field Depth. 2 out of 5. Modest field. Some fast riders in the mix. Value. 2 out of 5. Value is not the strong suit. Expenses. 1 out of 5. Premium pricing. Everything costs more here.
beats.editing_note: FAST PACING — 7 seconds per dimension. Quick-fire energy change from the deep analysis above. This is a PATTERN INTERRUPT through pacing shift.

beats.label: VERDICT
beats.narration: Verdict: Japanese Hokkaido Mountain Gravel. If you have a big budget and want a Japanese experience. maybe. For most riders. there are better options.
beats.editing_note: CLOSE THE MAIN LOOP. 0.5s silence before verdict. Tier badge slams in. Avatar delivers final take. DO NOT signal 'wrapping up' — maintain energy.
